Every week, we look back and highlight some of our favorite moments by emerging voices across the globe — like this cat enjoying some sun captured by @vital_rudak. For more of these photos, videos and news from around the community, visit the blog. (Link in profile.)
Photo by @vital_rudak

IndyCar driver Max Chilton (@maxchilton) knew he wanted to be in the racing business when he was just 8 years old. “My brother was already racing cars at the time,” Max says. “The smell of the burning rubber and the sound of the cars when I went to watch made me want to have a go.” Now 25, the rookie from Reigate, England, is set to compete in his first Indianapolis 500 (@indianapolismotorspeedway) after a successful stint as a Formula One driver in Europe. “I am fortunate enough to have already competed in two of the three biggest races in the world, Le Mans 24 Hours and the Monaco Grand Prix,” Max says. “I am now adding the fastest one of the three to that. The #Indy500 is the one all racing drivers want to win.”
Photo of @maxchilton by @chipganassiracing

A toppling tower of Post-its rises again in our #BoomerangOfTheWeek. “Most of the time the paper towers crashed before I could start to use #Boomerang,” German videographer and stop-motion artist Marcus Grysczok (@hypertrashwonderland) says. “My kids liked that!”
Follow @boomerangfrominstagram to see mind-blowing loops from our community.
#Boomerang by @hypertrashwonderland

Juan Cristóbal Cobo (@juancristobalcobo) captured this moment on a New York City Subway — it’s our first pick for The Week on Instagram. “I am fascinated by the people around me, by the chance encounters that happen every day in a city like New York,” says Juan, who was intrigued by this boy sitting across from him. “The shirt was oversized, and it looked more like it belonged to his father ... it raises questions that don’t necessarily have answers.”
Photo by @juancristobalcobo

It started with a pixie haircut. “People began telling me I looked like Audrey Hepburn,” Annelies van Overbeek (@anneliesvanoverbeek) says. After recognizing her resemblance to the actress, Annelies started re-creating iconic Hollywood looks. “I fell in love with the elegance and style of vintage silver screen glamour,” the 17-year-old history student from Belgium says. Annelies gathers most costumes from thrift stores and charity shops; it often takes over a month of planning before she’s ready to take a vintage selfie. Lots of looks are in the works, but soon, Annelies will travel to 16th century England to share her interpretation of Queen Anne Boleyn’s selfie style. “I’m really excited about that one!”
Photo by @anneliesvanoverbeek

Weekend Hashtag Project: #WHPwildthings

The goal this weekend is to make creative videos of the animal kingdom — like this one by @paulapaulova.

Here are some ideas to get started:
Showcase your pet’s personality by capturing them in their element – whether that’s mid-Frisbee in the backyard or curled up in a favorite nook.

Take a furry friend on a neighborhood adventure, and record your route with Instagram’s Hyperlapse app.

Don’t forget about animals in the wild! Explore the sights and sounds of nature like birds chirping in pine trees or dolphins breaching at the coast.

PROJECT RULES: Please add the #WHPwildthings hashtag only to videos taken over this weekend and only submit your own visuals to the project. If you include music in your submissions, please only use music to which you own the rights. Any tagged video taken over the weekend is eligible to be featured next week.

Video by @paulapaulova

Since grade school, Anthony Geathers (@anthonybgeathers) dreamed of becoming a United States Marine to help provide for his mother and brothers. The 26-year-old Brooklyn, New York, native deployed to Afghanistan twice. “I learned a lot about myself as a man and as a warrior,” Anthony says. “The same Marine Corps values I learned between boot camp and in the Fleet Marine Force — unbreakable determination, controlled aggression and a will to succeed — are things I apply in my growing career as a photographer.” Anthony found his niche sharing stories of athletes, particularly those in combat sports. “I get intimate with the fighters’ lives in their training camps, at home with their families and friends, backstage preparing for fights, the actual bout, their victories and defeats and the spectacle of the whole experience,” he says.
Photo by @anthonybgeathers

This week’s @music feature is on Kristin Welchez (@kristinkontrol), better known as Dee Dee, the frontwoman of garage rockers Dum Dum Girls. Though Kristin’s a seasoned performer now, growing up, she never felt comfortable performing the songs she loved to listen to. “I was incredibly introverted and shy,” she says, “so that was a pipe dream for a really long time.” That is until she released her debut solo album, “X-Communicate,” where she tapped into the sounds of her ‘80s new wave and R&B heroes. With the new record, Kristin was also able to indulge in her lighter, funnier side — as opposed to Dee Dee’s intimidating swagger, which was partially her way of combating stage fright. “I have my heavy moments for sure but I have a lot of light moments, too," she says. "I secretly harbor a desire to be a comedian, so this is working out perfectly.”
Photo of @kristinkontrol by @manute_bol_lives. Words by @music

Misha Vallejo (@mishavallejo) has his #EyesOn the social issues affecting Latin America’s most remote regions. “My work revolves around the ‘lost person’ and the ‘lost place,’” says the photojournalist, who has traveled to locations like Lake Poopó in Bolivia to learn more about the changing livelihoods of indigenous communities. The son of an Ecuadorian father and a Russian-Israeli mother, Misha’s inquisitive images reflect his own quest to understand where he fits into society: “I don’t want to explain everything to the viewer — I love shooting banal scenes of everyday life and giving them a twist.”
In Ecuador, where he says “the relationship between humans and nature is primordial and still very strong,” Misha reveals the society’s fragile relationship with a changing environment. Last month, he trained his lens on the coming together of communities along the Ecuadorian coast in response to a 7.8-magnitude earthquake: “We need to understand that we depend on our environment in order to survive.”
Photo by @mishavallejo

What goes up must come down — unless you’re Francesco Mattucci (@kitchensuspension). The concept of zero-gravity ingredients came to the Italian photographer from — where else? — his home kitchen in Modena, Italy. “The things that inhabit [the kitchen] get a life of their own,” Francesco says of the everyday items he creatively captures. He is secretive about his post-production magic, but Francesco will say this: “Every object that you see floating was captured in that exact spot.”
Photo by @kitchensuspension

“We love to perform and entertain people, and we feel at home on the stage. Our mum was a dancer and an acrobat and passed on her lifelong passion to us. This is #WhyIMove,” says 20-year-old Teagan Rybka (@teagan_rybka), one half of Australian acro-dance duo @rybkatwinsofficial with her twin sister, Sam (@sam_rybka). “Someone once told us that when they watch us it’s more like watching one person because of our strong unison, but dancing together is more challenging than people think. Trying to dance, execute acro-tricks and stay in perfect unison takes a lot of practice and patience. We’re both very similar in ability because we’ve worked together and pushed each other. We’ve spent most of our life upside down or on our hands down at the studio simply doing what we love!”
Photo by @rybkatwinsofficial

Charlotte Mei (@charlottemei_) believes worms are the most underrated creature in the animal kingdom. “They have no features or body parts, just one soft pink tube,” she says. “They are so funny.” Charlotte, an artist and illustrator who lives in London, spends time thinking about animals as she incorporates them into her ceramic works and drawings, often with a humorous wink. She also thinks about how her work may outlive her. “In 4,000 years, when all context is lost, how might someone interpret it?” asks Charlotte. “Will they think I worshipped worms? Do I?”
Photo by @charlottemei_

Kayak instructor Aleix Salvat (@aleixsalvat) is keeping up a family tradition. His parents were also kayak instructors who took Aleix out on his first trip at 4 years old — he’s been paddling the rapids of Europe and Latin America ever since. “I love how you feel in the water,” the adventure-seeker from Catalonia, Spain, says. “You feel so alive after making it through a difficult rapid.” Despite jumping a 78-foot (24-meter) waterfall on his most recent kayaking trip in Peru, Aleix is anything but reckless. “I’m usually frightened when facing tough rivers,” he says. “You always need to keep a cool head and analyze the situation.”
For more stories from the Spanish-speaking community, follow @instagrames.
Photo by @aleixsalvat

Meet Daredevil Meatball: the protein-packed thrill-seeker that Marwa Ebrahim (@marwaebrahim_me) created for #WHPedibleart and #FoodRevolutionDay. Marwa’s muse? Last night’s dinner. “I tried to imagine what a meatball might do if it had a life of its own,” the 21-year-old Bahraini student, who lives in Glasgow, Scotland, says.
Treat yourself to more tasty #WHPedibleart submissions for #FoodRevolutionDay on the blog. (Link in profile.) One may even inspire your next meal.
Video by @marwaebrahim_me

Danling Xiao (@mundane_matters) gave legs and life to an energetic carrot for last weekend’s hashtag project, #WHPedibleart.
Follow along as we feature some of our favorite submissions throughout the week, and check out more at blog.instagram.com.
Photo by @mundane_matters

Fairy tale magic pervades Laura Zalenga’s (@laura_zalenga_photography) images. “Even today, I have the Brothers Grimm book on my nightstand — it’s worn down from all the reading,” she says. The photographer from southern Germany doesn’t depict knights or frog princes, but she shares melancholic moments and magical places in her triptychs. “I like negative space a lot,” Laura says of her extreme landscape format. “The calm in it is something that’s important to me. I hope my pictures have the same effect on the viewer.”
For more stories from the German-speaking community, follow @instagramde.

Photo by @laura_zalenga_photography

Today’s #WeeklyFluff offers up a triple dose of feline fur. Meet Gümüş, Gazanfer and Akide (@sleepy_gumus), a trouble-making trio of Turkish kitties. For those looking to infuse their feed with a healthy helping of cuddly cat, follow @sleepy_gumus.
Video by @sleepy_gumus

Kiwi turtles and a blueberry octopus. That’s how you make healthy food fun. Vy Tran (@beyondsweetandsavory) came up with her submission for #WHPedibleart by thinking about how she gets her toddler to eat fruits and vegetables. The answer: help them look like a part of his favorite place — the ocean.
We’ll be serving up more interpretations of the project this week. Or, visit the blog for a full helping of healthy food dressed up in interesting ways. (Link in profile.)
Photo by @beyondsweetandsavory

Over the weekend, we asked you to make images featuring healthy, fresh food for #WHPedibleart and #FoodRevolutionDay. Here is one very creative take on the project — a fruit-tastic crown by @dehappy5_mama. 
Stay tuned for more delicious submissions, which will be featured here and on the blog. (Link in profile.)
Photo by @dehappy5_mama

“It’s a whole different world underwater,” shore diver Casey Tomasiak (@yesaccasey) says. “Most people don’t know what’s going on in the ocean.” A financial analyst by trade, Casey began documenting his dives off the coast of Singer Island, Florida, at the end of 2014. Manatees hold a special place in his heart, but it’s sea turtles who are his constant companions. He even helped facilitate the rescue of a loggerhead turtle whose shell was detaching. “Now, I know them so well I know when something is wrong with one of them,” the native Floridian says. “That’s pretty cool.” #WorldTurtleDay
Video by @yesaccasey

Timothy Wong (@timtast1c) is the champion of the “truly San Francisco butterfly,” the pipevine swallowtail. “People are surprised that it’s a native butterfly because it looks so tropical and exotic,” Timothy explains. “It’s actually a rare butterfly within the city limits because of all the habitat loss.” An aquarium biologist at the California Academy of Sciences (@calacademy), Timothy’s hobby of raising native butterflies at home has evolved into a successful conservation effort; his caterpillars and butterflies go to the San Francisco Botanical Garden, helping re-establish the population. “People get so jazzed when they hear it’s something they could be doing at home,” Timothy says. “That helps inspire people to start gardening and wildlife conservation in their very own backyard, much like I’ve done in my own.”
Photo by @timtast1c

Our final selection for The Week on Instagram comes from artist Fardin Nazari (@fardin.nazari). He captured this moment at the Rosewater Festival in Neyasar, Iran. 
Photo by @fardin.nazari

This photo of fireflies in a bamboo forest, our third pick for The Week on Instagram, was taken by Higuchi Takashi (@rekusan.jp) in Gifu, Japan. 
Photo by @rekusan.jp

Our second pick for The Week on Instagram is this photo from Slovakian photographer Mária Švarbová’s (@maria.svarbova) “In Swimming Pool” series. “My use of color is my style,” Mária says. “Through overexposed pastel tones, viewers are projected into a sanitized world in which people have given up any kind of individuality or extravagance. These pastel colors provide the perfect palette for minimalist work.”
Photo by @maria.svarbova

Every week, we look back and highlight some of our favorite emerging voices across the globe, like this photo captured by Roger Brufau Vilella (@roger_bv), who lives in Lleida, Spain, with his dog Pipo. For more of these photos, videos and news from around the community, visit blog.instagram.com. 
Photo by @roger_bv

Natsuhiko Kakutani (@daruma64) captured this slackline trick of a fellow festivalgoer at Mori-Michi-Ichiba in Gamagori, Japan. “I was not interested in video until recently. But when I started using Boomerang, my iPhone life has changed,” Natsuhiko says. 
Every week, we’ll be featuring a community member who takes looping to a whole new level. Nominate a #Boomerang that blows your mind by adding #BoomerangOfTheWeek to your caption. 
#Boomerang by @daruma64

“#hellomynameis Lara Wirth (@armageddonpainted). I am a 16-year-old from Melbourne, Australia. I started body painting on my 14th birthday. I was inspired by a reality TV show where they compete with special effects makeup. I begin any look by getting inspiration, usually from someone else’s body painting. Then I figure out what I like about it, and then I make it my own. I sketch it to see what it’s roughly going to look like, but by the time it reaches my body, it usually looks quite different. The really sad bit is washing it off — it’s a type of art that only exists in photos in the long haul. My dream would be to work on a movie or even just to watch another artist working in a professional setting. After finishing a creation, looking in the mirror can be a little frightening! I did once make a man scream in the supermarket when I rounded a corner right in front of him. He wasn’t prepared to be met by a zombie.”
Photo by @armageddonpainted

From @music, Mike Winkelmann (aka @beeple_crap) talks about his colorful concert visuals. In 2011, Mike attended Lollapalooza and was stunned to find his work plastered behind most of the performers. When he got home, he checked the stats of his Creative Commons uploads; his clips were being downloaded roughly 1,000 times a day. Since then, Mike has officially produced live visuals for Katy Perry, Justin Bieber and more. In those cases, he is one person in a team of about 10. It’s fun, but stressful — and not nearly as freeform as what he does with Zedd, having become the producer’s sole visual designer three years ago. “That was cool for me,” Mike says, about their ongoing collaboration and the work they did on Zedd’s recent “True Colors” tour. “When I got to see it live, it was like anybody else seeing it live. I didn’t know what was coming next.”
Photo by @beeple_crap. Words by @music

Weekend Hashtag Project: #WHPedibleart

Today is #FoodRevolutionDay, an event created by chef Jamie Oliver to drive positive change in food education and public health. To celebrate, the goal of this weekend’s project is to make photos and videos using healthy, fresh food in creative ways.

Here are some ideas to get started:

Visit a local farmers market, and pick up ingredients based on color and quirkiness.

Cook your favorite healthy dish, and style it in a new way — as a face or picture — or stage a scene entirely out of good-for-you snacks.

Bring fruits and vegetables to life in a playful #Boomerang or video.

PROJECT RULES: Please add the #WHPedibleart hashtag only to photos and videos taken over this weekend and only submit your own visuals to the project. If you include music in your video submissions, please only use music to which you own the rights. Any tagged photo or video taken over the weekend is eligible to be featured next week.

Featured photo by @meguccco

Chef and cooking instructor Terri Salminen (@terrisalminen) believes in simple, fresh ingredients. “An onion is really beautiful. A strawberry can be amazing,” she says. Terri was born in the United States, has called Haarlem, Netherlands, home for years and grew up in northern Italy, where her passion for food was cultivated. “In Italy, you breathe food and getting together around the table. That’s just normal,” she says. “I realized when I moved away that’s not everyone’s normal.”
An ambassador for Jamie Oliver’s Food Revolution since 2012, Terri is organizing an all-day cooking school (free of charge) for #FoodRevolutionDay at the restaurant Fifteen Amsterdam. “I believe that the good life starts at the kitchen table,” Terri says. “When you cook well, people eat well, and they feel happier. It’s a waterfall.” Terri urges novice, intimidated chefs to head straight to the source: “Go to a farmers market or go to a farm. Talk to someone who grew the food. They love it. That will help you to want to cook.”
Photo by @terrisalminen

“Every time I step onstage, I tell a story. I speak to the audience and I open up my soul. This is #WhyIMove,” says 17-year-old Moscow-based ballet dancer Stanislava Postnova (@ruby.tear). “It is hard work every day — a slow road toward technical perfection. Usually, I am at the Bolshoi Academy from 9 a.m. to 8 p.m. Sometimes I feel totally drained, but I am extremely proud to be studying here: a place full of centuries of Russian history. As a child, I used to choreograph for my friends, and in the future, I hope to make lifetime achievements as a ballerina and try choreography, too. I have so many creative ideas!”
Video by @ruby.tear

For the last seven MLB seasons, Joe Petruccio (@joey_paints) has captured the most memorable moments from every New York Mets game. Moments from wins come in color, while losses are remembered in black and white. “I kind of almost feel like I’m part of the team,” the lifelong fan and rock ‘n’ roll artist from Brooklyn, New York, says. “I feel like I’m getting ready to be called in to pitch, and the next morning I really feel like I need to come through.” Fortunately for Joe, the past few seasons have been quite colorful — the baseball team won the National League pennant in 2015. “There were some nights last year I couldn’t even wait for the morning,” Joe says. “I just stayed up, did the drawing and posted it.” Photo by @joey_paints

Prague-based artist and DJ Filip Hodas (@hoodass) constructs visual treats — objects and textures that harmonize in an atmosphere of surrealism. The 23-year-old former graphic designer is self-taught in 3-D art and embraces experimentation with every project. “Very often, I delete everything after hours of work, keep just one little detail I like and build a new scene around it,” Filip says. “With trial and error, you can learn practically anything. You’ll see how much better you can get really quickly!”
Photo by @hoodass

Every style Mobolaji Dawodu (@mobolajidawodu) captures tells a story. The costume designer and fashion editor credits his attention to detail to his childhood that started in Lagos, Nigeria, before he moved to Richmond, Virginia. “Traveling a lot when I was young and growing up in such extreme places made me more observant,” he says. Mobolaji moved to New York at 18 then landed an internship at the Dolce & Gabbana showroom where he began assisting stylists. Today, he serves as the fashion editor for GQ Style. “Observing life is the best research,” Mobolaji says. “Looking in the past and looking in the present in many ways dictates the future, especially in fashion.”
Photo by @mobolajidawodu

There’s a feeling of movement in almost all of Monique Jaques’ (@moniquejaques) photographs — even when the people in the photos are sitting or standing still. But that sense of motion isn’t surprising, given that Monique’s life has been something of a nonstop journey. Raised in New Jersey, Monique earned a fine arts degree at New York University before relocating six years ago to Istanbul. Since then she has worked throughout the Middle East, as well as in Africa and India, earning her living, in her words, as “a visual storyteller.” Monique’s storytelling emerges from patience and a sense of community with the people — especially the women — in her pictures. “Some of my colleagues are incredible street photographers. But that’s never been something I’ve done well,” Monique says. “On the other hand, I love things like weddings, brides. Those sorts of photographs are about closeness, a sense of intimacy. I couldn’t walk up to someone, take their photo and leave. Instead, I need to focus on the story, the history, the meaning behind my pictures.”
Photo by @moniquejaques

Last year, Eric Landon began posting mesmerizing high-speed videos and photos from the pottery wheel, and in doing so, entirely transformed Tortus (@tortus_copenhagen), his pottery studio in Denmark. “The most rewarding thing about what I do is acting as an inspiration for other potters around the world,” he says. Some of his followers are so inspired, they’re willing to travel across the globe to learn from the master himself — Landon now holds sold-out workshops to teach his craft. “Over 90 percent of my participants follow me on Instagram. And 80 percent are coming from abroad, as far as Japan, Australia and the US,” he says. Being open to new methods of communication with his followers has paid off: “It really blows my mind. This has created balance for my business, my creativity and for me as a person.”
Video by @tortus_copenhagen

“The trees are in the background, but they are the main character,” says Isabel Martinez (@isabelitavirtual), guest curator of last weekend’s hashtag project, #WHPhiddenbeauty, of this submission by @_yaisyusman_.

See more of our favorite submissions to the project at blog.instagram.com.

Photo by @_yaisyusman_

#WHPhiddenbeauty asked community members to look for moments of beauty in unexpected places.
“I love the strong combination of dark blue and orange,” says guest curator Isabel Martinez (@isabelitavirtual) of Davide Annibale’s (@dubyo) submission.

Follow along as we feature some of our favorite submissions throughout the week, and check out more at blog.instagram.com.

Photo by @dubyo

“Something is happening around her, but she’s in her world protected by the tree. Does she know that are we looking at her?” —guest curator Isabel Martinez (@isabelitavirtual) on Olya Kirillova’s (@fitwoman) submission to last weekend’s hashtag project, #WHPhiddenbeauty.

Follow along as we feature some of our favorite submissions throughout the week, and check out more at blog.instagram.com.

Photo by @fitwoman

“You don’t need a man. You need a manicure.” —the words Jessica Washick (@jessicawashick) loves to say when she makes a #tinycanvas out of a client’s nails. “It transcends hair texture, body type and skin color,” the nail artist from Portland, Oregon, says. “They’re something you can count on to amplify your mood or outfit — the same way you rely on a great bag or pair of shoes to pull your whole look together.” The former accessory designer started creating nail art as a form of therapy after breaking up with a long-term boyfriend. “Nail art creates a club that brings people together in a positive way.”
Photo by @jessicawashick

It’s time for your dose of #WeeklyFluff, Instagram. Today’s furry feature is a very regal beagle named Sid (@myregalbeagle). This uncharacteristically cool pizza-loving pooch exercises extraordinary restraint when in the presence of tempting treats. If your feed could use an infusion of snuggly snackaholic canine, follow @myregalbeagle.

Last weekend, #WHPhiddenbeauty asked community members to look for moments of beauty in unexpected places. The project took inspiration from guest curator Isabel Martinez (@isabelitavirtual), a creative director and photographer based in New York.
“The extraordinary beauty of an ordinary moment,” says Isabel of this submission from James Souder (@jdsouder). “Sometimes to capture beauty is effortless.”
Follow along as we feature some of our favorite submissions throughout the week, and check out more at blog.instagram.com.

Photo by @jdsouder

“How delicate is this? The combination of the white smoke transformed into an explosion of color,” says Isabel Martinez (@isabelitavirtual), the guest curator for #WHPhiddenbeauty, of this submission by @slevinaaron. “The technique in this photo is nice, but the soul is even better.”
Follow along as we feature some of our favorite submissions throughout the week, and check out more at blog.instagram.com.

Photo by @slevinaaron

#WHPhiddenbeauty asked community members to look for moments of beauty in unexpected places — like this one by Susan Bradley (@susanmbradley). The project took inspiration from guest curator Isabel Martinez (@isabelitavirtual), a creative director and photographer based in New York.
“Details are everything. We just need to listen to them. Not using just our eyes, but all of our senses,” Isabel says of this submission.

Follow along as we feature some of our favorite submissions throughout the week, and check out more at blog.instagram.com.

Photo by @susanmbradley

“I was pretty much always an entrepreneur. I wanted to give back to our planet, help people and work with a purpose,” explains Barbara Mattivy, the 31-year-old co-founder of Insecta Shoes (@insectashoes), a Brazilian small business that produces vegan eco-friendly footwear made out of vintage clothing and recycled plastic bottles. “I finally figured out I could combine my passions for fashion and the internet and still do good for the world.” Barbara’s advice to budding entrepreneurs is to follow your heart: “You’re one step ahead if you already know what your passion is. I see a lot of people nowadays wanting something different, but not sure of what it is. For those who already know, take advantage of this gift and think of ways to monetize it — usually it’s not that hard.” #LivingMyPassion

Photo by @insectashoes

“I went to school for graphic design. After I got out of college, I got a job at this alt weekly. We never really had a budget to hire good photographers, so I went to Best Buy and bought the sweetest camera I could find and just started shooting. After a couple years I was like, ‘Man, I enjoy this way more than sitting at a desk. I am going into photography full time.’ I was going to sink or swim, but it was going to be on my own terms.” —@jeremydeputat, a 38-year-old music photographer based in Detroit. Since 2009, he has toured with Eminem and Kid Rock, and taken photos of everyone from Odd Future to Dr. Dre.
Photo by @jeremydeputat. Words by @music

“#hellomynameis Oumaima Aurag (@lmmima). I am a 20-year-old business student from Casablanca, Morocco. I was raised with laughter, my father’s camera, my mother’s culture, road trips and — between two cups of mint tea — long conversations about home, roots and identity. The mix between my Amazigh roots and metropolitan Morocco upbringing makes the jumble of my identity what it is. I consider speaking five languages and carrying my different cultures and traditions a blessing. The Morocco I share with the world is a Morocco that is trying hard, in many ways, to grow, and I am trying to help in my own way. But more importantly, I share a Morocco that inspires me, excites me and makes me dream.”
Photo by @lmmima

It’s an imaginary world where Instagram logos grow out of the earth. Brooklyn-based illustrator Rachel Ryle (@rachelryle) used stop-motion animation to make this remix. “The story I wanted to convey was that from the old grows the new,” says the artist, who put hundreds of photos, seven hours of drawing, moving and coloring, and a cup of good old-fashioned dirt into her piece. “The final result of my work even surprises me sometimes, as I never fully know what it’s going to look like until the end.”
Video by @rachelryle

“In wedding photography, intuition and experience are two of the most important things to have,” photographer Pablo Laguía (@pablo_laguia) says. This photo taken in Chihuahua, Mexico, is our final pick for The Week on Instagram. “In that moment, I felt that the most interesting image would be from the distance, where you could see the bride next to her father,” Pablo, who lives in Orihuela, Spain, says. “Sometimes, you have to take a couple of steps back.”
Photo by @pablo_laguia

Photojournalist Sam Reinders (@samreinders) might not be a morning person, but it didn’t stop her from capturing this moment, one of our selections for The Week on Instagram, during a father-daughter car camping trip in Prince Albert, South Africa: “I threw the covers over my head at the first glint of dawn. I heard more groans from outside, and figured it was my dad — also not a morning person! But the groans grew in number and sounded funny. I rubbed a clearing in the frosted window and was greeted by 20 or so of these beautiful Angora goats. We’d camped near a windmill, and their feeding station, and they’d come for breakfast. I’m not quite sure who was more surprised.”
Photo by @samreinders

Rafael Mantesso (@rafaelmantesso) and his bull terrier, Jimmy Choo, combined artistic forces to remix our new look. Rafael provided the paint, Jimmy provided the paw power. According to Rafael, it took at least 10 attempts to get it just right. “Each like, each comment is like a hug for Jimmy,” Rafael says.

Photo by @rafaelmantesso

While driving through a car wash in New York City, art director Ryan Swierczek (@ryswiers) noticed water streaming down his windshield. It was the perfect opportunity to experiment with #Boomerang for the first time.

Every week, we’ll be featuring a community member who takes looping to a whole new level. Nominate a #Boomerang that blows your mind by adding #BoomerangOfTheWeek to your caption.

#Boomerang from @ryswiers

“I like the fact that you almost can’t tell whether it’s the 1940s or 2000s,” 23-year-old marketer and photographer Diane Villadsen (@dianewithonen) says of her photo taken on a blustery San Francisco rooftop, our second pick for the The Week on Instagram. “I wanted to play with this wind on the roof of Fort Point, rather than fight it. And having them jump was the perfect way to let the wind take control of their hair and skirts.”
Photo by @dianewithonen

Every week, we look back and highlight some of our favorite emerging voices across the globe, like this photo from Qazvin, Iran, captured by @maryam__shirdel. For more of these photos, videos and news from around the community, visit blog.instagram.com.

Photo by @maryam__shirdel

In Doro Ottermann’s (@doro_bot) animated illustration, colorful droplets magically stir into latte art of Instagram’s new look. “I often create short animations with dripping colored pencils, and I am (unfortunately) very much into coffee, so I combined those two things,” the artist from Hamburg, Germany, says. “The creative exchange with people on Instagram has inspired me to try different things and play with new ideas.”
Video by @doro_bot

Weekend Hashtag Project: #WHPhiddenbeauty

The goal this weekend is to look for moments of beauty in unexpected places. The project takes inspiration from guest curator Isabel Martinez (@isabelitavirtual), a creative director and photographer based in New York.

Isabel is known for her fashion images, characterized by strong lines and bold colors with an air of mystery. “I always work in the same direction, which is trying to capture what is hidden, a kind of poetry,” says Isabel.

Here are Isabel’s tips to get started:

Look for interesting scenes in everyday moments: “We are surrounded by beauty — it depends on you to see where it is.”
Focus on photographing details without showing the entire scene: “For me, the most interesting photo is when the viewer is able to add part of the missing information from his own experience.”
PROJECT RULES: Please add the #WHPhiddenbeauty hashtag only to photos and videos taken over this weekend and only submit your own visuals to the project. If you include music in your video submissions, please only use music to which you own the rights. Any tagged photo or video taken over the weekend is eligible to be featured next week.

Photo by @isabelitavirtual

For the 69th year, celebrities, moviemakers and fans are in the South of France for the Cannes Film Festival (@festivaldecannes). Some are veterans, like 10-time attendee photographer Greg Williams (@gregwilliamsphotography). Others are newcomers to the festivities. Julia Roberts may be a household name around the world, but it’s her first time at Cannes — her movie “Money Monster” premiered at the festival. Greg captured this video of Julia, who was waving at a little girl in a cabana as she prepared to pose. “Cannes is so crazy,” Greg says about choosing the setting for the portrait, which was about 10 minutes from the festivities. “And the peace you feel by the sea relaxes you immediately.”
Video by @gregwilliamsphotography

Illustrator Lucie de Moyencourt (@studio_lucie_de_moyencourt) is capturing the spectacle of the Cannes Film Festival (@festivaldecannes) through a series of short animated films. “I have never felt so stimulated to capture moments as I did walking on Boulevard de la Croisette this morning,” Lucie says. “Visually, it’s a treat!” Beyond the glamour — and in the midst of the chaos — Lucie appreciates the locals who go about their regular business and the tall, unyielding palm trees.

Video by @studio_lucie_de_moyencourt

Beware ... it’s #Fridaythe13th. Don’t break a mirror or let a black cat cross your path — unless it’s a spooky likeness of the one in this image by David Moreno Garcia (@deivitt). David lives in Barcelona, Spain, where his feline muse called Noir was adopted. “When I was visiting the shelter, he was the only cat that passed through my legs, as if he was choosing me,” David, who actually isn’t superstitious, says. Rather, he believes Noir brings good luck, despite the cat’s tricky ways. “He likes to climb over the highest parts of the house, and try to stay hidden, as if you can’t see him.”
Photo by @deivitt

Gabriel Scanu (@gabscanu) can’t fly through the air to achieve his aerial views of Australia — a drone does the heavy lifting. Last year, Gabriel and his father, a cinematographer, began capturing breathtaking images of his native country from hundreds of feet in the air, opening eyes all over the world to its diversity. “Being Australian, foreigners always think of you as a farmer, riding to work on a kangaroo through the bush everyday,” he says. “Growing up in the booming city of Sydney, my experiences of Australia are far from this assumption.”
Drone photography is relatively easy, Scanu promises, even in bad weather. “I think the most appealing aspect is the adrenaline and excitement of operating such an amazing piece of technology,” he says. “It’s almost like a sport, going into it and not knowing what the outcome will be, or if you’ll even get the drone back at the end of it.”
Photo by @gabscanu

Artist and photographer Philippa Stanton’s (@5ftinf) rendition of Instagram’s new look was made from a collection of eclectic — yet recognizable — odds and ends. “The ordinary tape measure, which I used for the outline, represents an everyday connection,” Philippa, who lives in Brighton, England, says. “A massive part of Instagram for me is connecting with people.” For that reason, she also incorporated a doll in the remix — a gift from someone Philippa met on the platform. “Not only is this doll small, like me,” she says, "but it represents an Instagram friendship that became a real friendship outside of the digital world, too.”
Photo by @5ftinf

“I come from a family full of dance and music. In a way, I am carrying on a tradition. This is #WhyIMove,” says Venice Beach, California, B-Boy David Shreibman (@_kiddavid_). “Dance for me is a pure form of being in the moment; I don’t think about anything but the music and reacting. I am a movement artist — I love seeing all the ways I can use my body to create pictures and movement.”
Video by @_kiddavid_

Three years ago, Paulo del Valle (@paulodelvalle) started the My Instagram Logo project, inspiring thousands of creators to remix our icon in wildly creative ways. Paulo, who lives in São Paulo, used more than 400 flowers to make his remix of our app’s new look. “I went to the biggest flower shop in Rio de Janeiro and bought half of their stock for Mother’s Day. Then I got home and I had no idea how I was going to do it,” he explains. Eight hours later, he had something beautiful.

Photo by @paulodelvalle

We have a new look! Earlier today we announced an updated icon and app design for Instagram, inspired by the amazing things you do. The Instagram community has evolved over the past five years from a place to share filtered photos to so much more — a global community of interests sharing more than 80 million photos and videos every day. Get more details on the blog. (Link in bio)

Today we’re introducing a new look. You’ll see an updated icon and app design for Instagram. Inspired by the previous app icon, the new one represents a simpler camera and the rainbow lives on in gradient form. You’ll also see updated icons for our other creative apps: Layout, Boomerang and Hyperlapse.

We’ve made improvements to how the Instagram app looks on the inside as well. The simpler design puts more focus on your photos and videos without changing how you navigate the app.

The Instagram community has evolved over the past five years from a place to share filtered photos to so much more — a global community of interests sharing more than 80 million photos and videos every day. Our updated look reflects how vibrant and diverse your storytelling has become.

Thank you for giving this community its life and color. You make Instagram a place to discover the wonder in the world. Every photo and video — from the littlest things to the most epic — opens a window for people to broaden their experiences and connect in new ways.

“My daughter spreads her arms without fear because she feels safe under our protection,” says Nacho Rodríguez Perez (@naseke) of Valencia, Spain. “She is a magical girl.”
Nacho created this image of himself, his wife and daughter for last weekend’s hashtag project, #WHPfamilytree. See more of our favorite submissions on blog.instagram.com.

Photo by @naseke

Khodayar Ahi (@godyar) from Tehran compiled family faces from the past and present for his submission to #WHPfamilytree.

Follow along as we feature some of our favorite submissions throughout the week, and check out more at blog.instagram.com.

Video by @godyar

French writer and photographer Romain Esteban (@romestebanr) photographed four young skaters for last weekend’s hashtag project, #WHPfamily. “In life they are like brothers. All the challenges they make together, hand-in-hand,” he says.

Follow along as we feature some of our favorite submissions throughout the week, and check out more at blog.instagram.com.

Photo by @romestebanr

“I heard a lot about the Second World War from my grandmothers,” Arthur Bondar (@arthurbondar), a Moscow-based photographer from Ukraine, says. “When one of them passed away, I realized she was in the generation who saw the horrors of war with their own eyes. My other grandmother read a letter she wrote during the war. It described everything that was happening.” This letter was the impetus for Arthur’s book, “Signatures of the War,” a project documenting the destinies changed by war.

Arthur met with 70 World War II veterans who each have their own unique story and cherished photographs. “When I was listening, I imagined them young and full of energy, they had just begun to live,” he says. “At the end of our talk, every veteran autographed their photo, but in the same moment they left a mark on the photo, they also left one in my heart.”
Photo by @arthurbondar

Today’s #WeeklyFluff is for avian aficionados everywhere. Rio and Tweety (@irn_rio) are an adorable duo of Indian ringneck parrots from Croatia. These brilliantly colored birds will peck, chirp and coo their way into your heart. If your feed is depressingly devoid of feathered fluff, consider following @irn_rio.

Photographer Mindy Johnson (@mindymoveit) captures a mother-daughter workout routine for last weekend’s hashtag project, #WHPfamilytree.

Follow along as we feature some of our favorite submissions throughout the week, and check out more at blog.instagram.com.

Photo by @mindymoveit

Canadian artist Charlotte Hamilton (@blueshineart) created this illustration of her mother to celebrate her family and heritage for last weekend’s hashtag project, #WHPfamilytree.

Follow along as we feature some of our favorite submissions throughout the week, and check out more at blog.instagram.com.

Video by @blueshineart

#WHPfamilytree asked community members to make photos and videos celebrating their family and heritage — like this one by @everydayastronaut.

Follow along as we feature some of our favorite submissions throughout the week, and check out more at blog.instagram.com.

Photo by @everydayastronaut

Multidisciplinary artist John McLaughlin (@jhnmclghln) identifies with the hair he often depicts in animations, sketches and paintings. “I never like doing one thing or settling on one medium,” says John, who lives in New York. “I feel like hair can do the same: If it wants to curl one way one day and wave that way the next, it will.”
John’s fascination with furry textures and his experiments with 3-D programs led to the creation of a reoccurring character — Fuzzy Dude — who has been known to make appearances, whether meeting up with Cleo the Bunny (@cleo_thebunny) or hanging out with models during New York Fashion Week. “Everything I see, touch and smell inspires me,” says John. “I gravitate toward human, honest and humorous things.”
Video by @jhnmclghln

“Мy dog Oliver likes to swim — he will swim even through the ice,” says Maria Sumlinova (@cody_shannimal_), a student from Moscow. “I thought that it would be amazing if I took a photo of him jumping into the water,” she adds about this picture, one of our picks for The Week on Instagram. “It’s like he is flying!😉”
Photo by @cody_shannimal_

Ramón Espinosa Tebar (@aprespinosa) is another one of our featured photographers from The Week on Instagram with this photo from the Chanel fashion show in Havana. “I am thinking of cowboy movies,” says Ramón, a photographer for the Associated Press originally from Spain. “All were gathered waiting to pick up clients as if they were riders with their horses.”
Photo by @aprespinosa

“Motherhood is by far the coolest thing I have done and do every day,” says Sora Ceballos-Lopez (@soraceballos) of raising her 10-year-old daughter, Gaby. “It is a complete surrender of love and an inexplicable combination of happiness, joy and fear.” While still pregnant, Sora began collecting mother-daughter themed figurines, dolls and artwork that inspired her to begin doodling — something she hadn’t done since high school. Now, Sora, who is from Medellín and lives in New Jersey, is nearly halfway through a New Year’s challenge to create an illustration celebrating motherhood each day: everything from moments of pride and fear to times that are simply silly.
#MothersDay this year is a particularly special occasion for Sora. Her own mother, who turns 75 this month, will be visiting from Colombia. “Call [your mother] every day,” she urges other moms, “thank her and tell her how much you understand her now.”
Photo by @soraceballos

“When I travel, I encounter a feeling, an awareness of something in the air that the camera isn’t capable of capturing,” says Hernan Castelli (@hellorayita), one of our featured photographers from The Week on Instagram. “I started to intervene in my photos to reflect that.” Hernan, an illustrator and graphic designer from Buenos Aires, Argentina, is especially drawn to the ocean. “It is still one of those things that remains a mystery — who knows what’s in there that we don’t know?”
Photo illustration by @hellorayita

Pablo Navajas Valentini (@navajaspablo) from Mexico City is one of our featured photographers from The Week on Instagram. “I like the combination of that ephemeral construction, only living for a few hours, with the bell tower of a chapel built several centuries ago,” says Pablo of the temporary wooden structure constructed for the celebration of Santa Catarina. “The people in the picture give it scale and the light completes the circle.”
Photo by @navajaspablo

It’s one thing to be able to stand on your hand. Parisian break dancer Arnaud Deprez (@arnauddeprez1) has figured out how to hit the floor — or rather, hit the street — and spin forever.

Every week, we’ll be featuring a community member who takes looping to a whole new level. Nominate a #Boomerang that blows your mind by adding #BoomerangOfTheWeek to that post’s comments.

#Boomerang from @arnauddeprez1

No request is too outlandish for Rachel Bell and Kate Welsh (@thehatgirls). “We do a lot of unorthodox, unconventional materials,” says Rachel. “We’ve made hats out of hair before. We’ve made hats out of tree branches.” Constructing their own Lady Gaga-esque hats started as a hobby, but after turning heads for several years, the two turned their passion into a business. Depending on how unique the request, creating a one-of-a-kind headpiece takes anywhere from five to 24 hours to put together. This year for the Kentucky Derby (@kentuckyderby), the pair will fulfill about 150 custom orders. “The most important part of the Derby is the fashion,” Rachel says. “No woman wants to see their hat on somebody else!”
Photo by @thehatgirls

Sara and Rich Combs of the Joshua Tree House (@thejoshuatreehouse) fell in love with the California desert the first time they visited. “It makes you feel like you can be yourself and create what you want to create,” Rich says. Last May, the couple, both 29 years old, found themselves with a 1940s hacienda, which they renovated and listed for rental online about five months later. When they’re in San Francisco, Rich and Sara work as web designers, designing apps for startups and tech companies. They used their backgrounds to redo the house’s interiors, curate art on the walls and add touches reminding guests to take life slow — from flipping a record on a vintage player to brewing a cup of pour-over coffee. “We want people to enjoy the process of creating something, even if it’s just coffee,” Rich says. Their advice to other small business owners on Instagram is to remember that snapping a single photo is never as compelling as telling an entire story. “The story of Joshua Tree obviously captured us,” says Sara. “We figured out how we can share that feeling with people who are interested in staying at the house.”
Photo of @thejoshuatreehouse by @beccatapert

Weekend Hashtag Project: #WHPfamilytree

The goal this weekend is to make photos and videos celebrating your family and heritage — like this one by @caronzito. Here’s how to get started:
Take still or video portraits of immediate and extended family members together that highlight similarities in appearance or personality across generations. 
Look for objects around your home that illustrate your family’s story, such as old photographs or treasured heirlooms.

Include captions that explain more about your unique family history and the people depicted in your submission. 
PROJECT RULES: Please add the #WHPfamilytree hashtag only to photos and videos taken over this weekend and only submit your own visuals to the project. If you include music in your video submissions, please only use music to which you own the rights. Any tagged photo or video taken over the weekend is eligible to be featured next week.

Featured photo by @caronzito

Finding the best views of space from Earth requires Matthew Newman (@matthewnewmanphotography) to brave the darkness. “Most people find it kind of scary ... You’re out in the wild by yourself most of the time,” the professional window-tinter and night photographer from Medford, Oregon, says. “Many people don’t have the opportunity to experience the night sky the way that I’m able to,” Matthews says; due to light pollution, most of the world’s population can no longer see the Milky Way with the naked eye: “I try to capture it as best as possible, as natural as possible. Hopefully, it will inspire people, more than anything, to drive away from the city and actually go see it for themselves.”
Photo by @matthewnewmanphotography

“#MyStory is about making the most of the opportunities I’ve been given and sharing the stories and experiences of young people all over the world.” —Kiana Hayeri (@kianahayeri), the 27-year-old IWMF fellow and recipient of the Chris Hondros Fund Award in the Emerging Photographer category, says. She has been based in Kabul since November 2014.
“When I moved to Canada from Iran in grade 11, I didn’t speak any English, and photography became my link to my environment. One summer back in Iran, I started photographing my friends, and it started growing into a bigger project about youth in Iran and then, Afghanistan. I know all we hear in the news is the war, the conflict, the human rights abuse, but at the same time in Afghanistan, there’s a group of young people who go to cafes and hang out. Life goes on no matter what. From time to time, I meet some amazing young women, often even younger than I am, who are very ambitious, know exactly what they want and don’t see themselves as victims. They think if anything has to change, they are responsible to change that. Not anyone else.”
#MyStory is a series that spotlights inspiring women in the Instagram community. Join the conversation by sharing your own story.

Photo by @kianahayeri

“I was one of those little boys who would hide behind his mum’s leg and not speak to anyone. But then, I had my first ballet lesson at age 7: It was like the whole world burst open. I was free! This is #WhyIMove,” says Steven McRae (@stevenmcrae_), a Royal Ballet principal dancer at London’s Royal Opera House (@royaloperahouse). “There’s a moment just before the curtain comes up when everything becomes quiet — the orchestra stops tuning, and you get this rush of adrenaline. Dancers have an addiction to work, because there’s always something to improve. But we’re not robots or athletes, we’re artists trying to tell a story with our bodies.”
Video by @stevenmcrae_

For photographer Cassandra Giraldo (@cassandragiraldo), the After School Project (@afterschoolproject) began as a creative break from newspaper assignments. It helped that she lives across the street from one of New York City’s largest high schools. “I would always catch myself taking portraits of teens in the city,” she says. “I realized I had a wealth of youth right in front of me to work with.” About twice a week, she goes for “walkabouts” in her neighborhood to capture the embrace of high school lovers, the moment after a football huddle or a pair doing math homework in the park. “What’s great about teenagers is that they don’t wear masks like us adults do,” she says. “They’re completely themselves, which makes it such a fascinating subject matter.”
Photo by @afterschoolproject

In anticipation of #ChildrensDay in Japan, carp streamers fly fancifully against the blue sky. This year Morio Okada (@_morio_), who lives in Gunma prefecture of Japan, discovered a spot in his hometown full of these banners: Hokubu Sports Park in the city of Ota. “It was really a sight to behold: a vast expanse of orange poppies, pink mountain phlox and blue nemophila flowers, and there, in one corner, all these carp banners dancing in the wind,” he says of the park. “It’s a place that I find myself wanting to visit in the first few days of April every year, when the cherry trees are in full bloom and it’s stunningly beautiful.”
Photo by @_morio_

“Judge me by my size, do you?” —Yoda
Video by @pinot #MayThe4thBeWithYou

“TK-421, why aren’t you at your post?”
Photo by @troopersdaily #MayThe4thBeWithYou

“My inspiration was to reflect pure spring,” says Mònica Gómez Montero (@monicamakanakis) from Barcelona, Spain, of this photo she created celebrating her mother. “It was a beautiful moment full of laughter.”
#WHPdaydream asked community members to make surreal photos and videos inspired by their dreams.

Photo by @monicamakanakis

“I think everyone’s entitled to a bit of daydreaming once in a while, and that’s exactly what I’m doing in this video. Just simply let your mind wander off.” —Barbara Tempelman (@bbvangroningen), a public relations editor from Groningen, Netherlands.

#WHPdaydream asked community members to make surreal photos and videos inspired by their dreams.

Video by @bbvangroningen

“I’ve spent a long time looking for that place your mind wanders during a long day at the office... That was the place we found this weekend,” says Dani Chase (@quequequeso), a community manager living in Los Angeles. “Everybody just wants to frolic.”
#WHPdaydream asked community members to make surreal photos and videos inspired by their dreams.

Photo by @quequequeso

Three years and over 1,000 photographs later, Brazilian journalist Gabriela Saueia is not bored of sunsets. For her project “Depois das Seis” (@depoisdasseis), Gabriela captures the sunset every day in her hometown of São Paulo. “There will never be two photographs which are exactly the same, nor will we ever see the same sky or sunset,” she says. “My favorite photographs are those taken after a rainy or cloudy day. This reminds me that nothing is permanent and everything can change in an instant.”
Photo by @depoisdasseis

It’s #WeeklyFluff time, and today’s feature is for feline fanatics. Say hello to Anago (@anago_in_yokohama), a marvelously handsome blue-eyed rescue kitty from Japan. For those feeling that their feed is lacking in cuddly kitty fluff, follow @anago_in_yokohama.

At the Met Gala on Monday, filmmaker Gordon von Steiner (@gvsgvs) created video portraits of the iconic guests for Vogue (@voguemagazine) on a small set inspired by the event’s theme, Manus x Machina: Fashion in an Age of Technology. “The idea is to take the traditional photo booth and flip it on its head,” says Gordon, who lives in New York, “to create something futuristic and unexpected.” Gordon’s work always revolves around constructing a cinematic fantasy through fashion. “The viewer is brought out of normalcy into a world where characters move and behave in bizarre and beautiful ways,” Gordon says. “It’s my goal to evoke an emotional reaction in the viewer and not question why the woman is dancing alone in the mansion or having an out of body experience as she touches a handbag.”
Video by @gvsgvs

“I used to have toy unicorns when I was little,” says Vicky Martinez (@m.vicky.m), a lawyer who lives in Buenos Aires, Argentina. #WHPdaydream asked community members to make surreal photos and videos inspired by their dreams. Vicky made this image after a trip to the countryside for a friend’s birthday. “This horse, far away, so magic, so beautiful, was such a mystical experience,” she says. “I feel a special connection with nature — the inspiration it brings me everyday to keep taking pictures and enjoying life.”
Photo illustration by @m.vicky.m

“Over the last couple of weeks I've been waking up every single morning to enjoy the sunrise and document it,” says architecture student Karl “Shakur” Ndieli (@karl_shakur). On his 16th sunrise, Karl headed to San Francisco’s Marin Headlands. “I spotted all the dust particles and small rocks dancing in the air behind me, glinting in the morning light … I immediately pulled over on the shoulder to replicate the daydream I had just experienced.”
#WHPdaydream asked community members to make surreal photos and videos inspired by their dreams.

Video by @karl_shakur

#WHPdaydream asked community members to make surreal photos and videos inspired by their dreams — like this one by @angrylittlenotion.

Follow along as we feature some of our favorite submissions throughout the week, and check out more at blog.instagram.com.

Photo by @angrylittlenotion

Rick Williams (@rickwlms) bought his sneaker boutique, Burn Rubber (@burnrubberdetroit), when he was just 23 years old. No easy feat for a new college graduate. “I got into photography because of my sneaker store. I had to shoot the product because we didn’t have money to pay a real photographer,” Rick, now 35, says. “I just got to the point where that was my favorite part of the whole process.” Telling stories through photos is Rick’s creative passion these days, and scenes from Detroit are often his muse: “When I shoot around out here, I’ve been in a lot of abandoned buildings and things like that,” Rick, who lives in Southfield, Michigan, a Detroit suburb, says. “But I find a lot of beauty in that heritage, imagining what used to be there and what that building used to be like ... We’re making it here. We’re still driving. There’s a beauty in that to me; there’s a beauty in the struggle.” #SmallBusinessWeek

Photo by @rickwlms

“Every doll is a unique story for me,” Lia Selina (@liaselina), an illustrator from Ramenskoye, Russia, says. She started working in computer animation, but after giving birth to her daughter, Alice, and reconnecting with her love of fairy tales, Lia went back to basics with a notebook and color pencils and began drawing unique dolls. “My inspiration comes from the nature — flowers, trees, birds, wind and water. Every season of the year brings new ideas and, of course, I love fairy tales.”
Photo by @liaselina

Nastaran Farjadpezeshk (@nastaran__fp) is one of our featured voices from The Week on Instagram with this photo from a rainy afternoon in Iran. “Two kids caught my attention while asking their parents for their mobile phone. At first I thought they wanted to play with it, but then I realized they actually wanted to take a picture of the rainbow,” says Nastaran, an electrical engineering professor. “There are always moments in our lives that we as adults can’t actually see.”
Photo by @nastaran__fp

April 30 is the last White House Correspondents’ Dinner for this presidency, and to mark the occasion, the collage artist Pablo Thecuadro (@thecuadro) created new works featuring classic images from past dinners, starring icons like Carolyn Bessette Kennedy and Sylvester Stallone. “I begin when I see pictures that I love, and I start thinking how I could transform them,” says the artist who lives in Madrid. “I finish when I’ve tried every combination and chosen the one I like the most.” Pablo, who worked with W Magazine (@wmag) on this series, says that of the three images, the one from the ‘70s is his favorite. “I love the photographs from that decade,” he says. “With these images, I wanted to express something joyful and glamorous, a party that you would want to go to.”
Photo by @thecuadro

Californian Jennifer Diamond (@nifer) is one of our featured voices from The Week on Instagram with this video from San Francisco’s Ocean Beach. “I could barely see what was happening because the sun was blinding,” says Jennifer, who was pleasantly surprised by the result. “That day I felt a strong connection to the seagulls. The powerful force of the wind brought us together.”
Video by @nifer

Firoz Merchant (@firoz_merchant) is one of our featured voices from The Week on Instagram with this photo from Mumbai. Firoz, an entrepreneur and photographer, was on his way to a meeting when he encountered this otherworldly moment. “The man sitting on the truck, while it’s moving ... he is extremely calm and settled,” Firoz says.

Photo by @firoz_merchant

Weekend Hashtag Project: #WHPdaydream

The goal this weekend is to make surreal photos and videos inspired by your dreams — like this one by @una_blue. Here’s how to get started:
Stage a reality- or gravity-defying moment, like tossing objects into the air to make them appear as if they’re magically floating.

Create a psychedelic dreamscape by shooting through tinted materials or turning your camera for a distorted perspective.

If shooting video, consider a plot twist that transforms an ordinary situation into a fantasy.

PROJECT RULES: Please add the #WHPdaydream hashtag only to photos and videos taken over this weekend and only submit your own visuals to the project. If you include music in your video submissions, please only use music to which you own the rights. Any tagged photo or video taken over the weekend is eligible to be featured next week.

For more examples and inspiration, check out blog.instagram.com.

Featured video by @una_blue

Today on @music … “Views.” Almost two years in the making, Drake’s (@champagnepapi) new record is as much about his life and the people in it — including his mom, Sandi Graham — as it is his current dominance of the music world writ large. Since first announcing the record back in 2014, Drake has been busy, dropping two buzzworthy mixtapes as well as the single “Hotline Bling” (and its neon-hued music video). Now, it’s all about the new album — which, according to Drizzy, is “based around the climate shift in Toronto.” “Our summers don’t last that long so we pack as much as we can in, and I’ve tried to get that across with this particular project,” he says. “If you enjoy my music, this will hopefully be in the top two or three albums that I have ever put out.”
Photo of @champagnepapi by @theo.skudra

“My dance is neither a philosophy nor a job; it is the way I am feeling emotionally. This is #whyImove,” Moscow-based dancer Olga Kuraeva (@kuraevaolga) says. “I am not an actress. If I am not going through a certain emotion, I won’t be able to express it through dance. It doesn’t matter if I dance well or not — the most important thing is that I am real. The Bolshoi Ballet Academy is my childhood, my youth and my present, but I don’t have ballet idols. I am really inspired by people who do extreme sports. I think they are brave and emotionally very strong. The stage never gives you a second chance, so I prefer photos and videos. The camera is able to capture real and deep emotions. I can see myself developing in that direction in the future.”
Photo of @kuraevaolga by @ayakovlevcom

The expansion of the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art (@sfmoma) includes a second entrance and soaring atriums — light-filled and welcoming places where visitors can spend time for free and view art even if they’re not planning
 a full museum visit. “It’s a way for the museum to say that this is a new gallery, a new type of work, with a new mission to bring people inside,” says Jon McNeal, the project architect at Snøhetta (@snohetta), the firm that designed the expansion.

The elements in the museum that Jon expects will be photographed the most include the entryways, the dynamic new façade of the building and — perhaps surprisingly — the restrooms. “We designed them to be a visual reset for your eyes,” says Jon, describing facilities that relate to the artwork on each floor and are bathed in the same bright color from floor to ceiling, whether magenta or fire-engine red or bright green. “It’s a clear punctuation mark for your visit,” he says. “When you go back to the gallery, it’s as if you’re entering it for the first time.”
Photo of @sfmoma by @henrikkamfoto

When we first built Instagram for Windows, we were focused on bringing the app’s core features to the Windows Phone community as quickly as possible. Today, we’re rolling out Instagram for Windows 10 Mobile with all of the community’s favorite features — including Instagram Direct, Explore and video.

You’ll also see that Instagram for Windows 10 Mobile supports Live Tiles, showing you updates right on your home screen.

You can learn more about Instagram for Windows 10 Mobile in the Instagram Help Center.

Instagram for Windows 10 Mobile is rolling out today in the Windows Store.

Braxton Miller (@braxtonmiller) is a man on the verge of having his lifelong dream come true. “I have been praying for this moment since I was 6-years-old,” Braxton says about the opportunity to be selected in the NFL draft this week. “Whichever team I go to, I’m going to be the same person, and I’m going to work even harder,” he says. The future hasn’t always been so clear for Braxton. The one-time star quarterback at Ohio State was forced to change positions to wide receiver his senior year after a devastating shoulder injury. He hopes his hard work sheds light on the kind of person he is. “There are all types of good players and competition in the league,” Braxton says. “So I just want to be the best I can be.” Photo of @braxtonmiller by @emadrashidi

“#hellomynameis Rhiannon McGavin (@mermaideleh). I’m 18 years old and I live in Los Angeles.

In ninth grade, the Get Lit program came to my school. Students choose a classic poem, write a response and compete with their response in an annual poetry slam. My poem was ‘A Smile to Remember’ by Charles Bukowski — and my response was about how much I hated getting catcalled walking home from school. I scored straight 10s in the classic slam, so they recruited me to represent Los Angeles for Brave New Voices, an international spoken word competition for teenagers. Things definitely went crazy from there.

Growing up, my mom and I weren’t able to go on a lot of family vacations, but last year, I was asked to perform at the Women in the World summit in New York. New York is where my mom grew up, and it’s her favorite city in America. I was able to take my mom there for a week because of my poetry.

Next year, I’m going to be an English major at UCLA with a minor in developmental psychology. This is my secret dream: I want to produce a children’s show or a children’s book series about Shakespeare and classical literature.”
#NationalPoetryMonth

Video by @mermaideleh

“Something that looks industrial, mechanical and complex can also have an elegant and refined nature,” says Molistudio (@molistudio) designer Sebastián Dias. He and his Argentine colleagues, Ignacio Gómez and Jonatan Basaldúa, turn ordinary objects into colorful pieces of industrial design with their looping GIF animations. Whether they’re experimenting with playful robots or building 3-D cities, they call their job “an excuse to communicate and tell stories.”
Video by @molistudio

Chulsu Kim (@chulsukim) has three tenets for extraordinary street photography: “Go with your instincts. Take lots of photos. Just keep walking.” The photographer, who is originally from Yamaguchi, Japan, has a knack for capturing candid expressions throughout the streets, parks and metro stations of Tokyo. “No matter who the subject is, there is always a moment when they become a great actor,” he says. “I feel a tremendous buzz when I come across such moments.” After a day collecting hundreds of photos, Chulsu feels exhilarated and connected to the city’s pulse: “Directly experiencing the ever-changing urban environment and the way people live — it’s really stimulating.”
Photo by @chulsukim

Last weekend, thousands of people like model, writer and activist Cameron Russell (@cameronrussell) gathered for the 13th Worldwide InstaMeet to celebrate Earth Day while taking photos and videos together. With the New York City Department of Cultural Affairs (@nyculture), Cameron organized an InstaMeet at Materials for the Arts (@materialsforthearts), a reuse center where fashion houses can drop off materials for not-for-profit organizations like public schools and hospitals to repurpose. “Materials for the Arts upcycling 1.5 million pounds [680,400 kilograms] last year of fashion’s fabric that was headed for the trash is proof that a sustainable future is not one of scarcity, but of abundance,” Cameron says.

Check out #LifeOnEarthWWIM13 and #WWIM13 to see how our amazing community celebrated in every corner of the world.

#Boomerang by @cameronrussell

Last weekend, thousands of people like @kenta_soyoung gathered for the 13th Worldwide InstaMeet to celebrate Earth Day and explore nature while taking photos and videos together. Check out #LifeOnEarthWWIM13 and #WWIM13 to see how our amazing community celebrated in every corner of the world.
#Boomerang by @kenta_soyoung

Last weekend, thousands of people like 19-year-old student Christoph Stoeter (@christophcolon) gathered for the 13th Worldwide InstaMeet to celebrate Earth Day while taking photos and videos together.

Christoph attended an InstaMeet just outside of Frankfurt, Germany, where he took this photo of his friend Thomas. “There is nothing better than being in nature and to be blown away by it’s beauty,” says Christoph. “It was one of those moments when you realize you’re in the right place at the right time.”
Check out #LifeOnEarthWWIM13 and #WWIM13 to see how our amazing community celebrated in every corner of the world.

Photo by @christophcolon

As a woman born in the US to Saudi parents, Tasneem Alsultan (@tasneemalsultan) often felt like an outsider — someone not fully embraced by or comfortable in the cultures that shaped her. “I was a third culture kid,” Tasneem, 30, says of her formative years. “I didn’t react to things the same way my parents did, but I also didn’t look like what many people think of as a typical American. It took me a long time to be OK with that.” Today, Tasneem’s photography ranges from spontaneous, joy-filled wedding portraits to more recent documentary work on the private lives of Saudi women. All of her pictures are filtered through a sensibility born from one abiding hope: that she can capture what unites diverse cultures, rather than what divides them. “In my photography, I am trying to mediate between worlds,” Tasneem says. “It’s a kind of activism. I’m rebelling against stereotypes by portraying people, and especially women and girls, as they really are.”
Photo by @tasneemalsultan

Today’s #WeeklyFluff is for those who shower love on shibas. Meet Fricko (@umigiva): a snuggle-loving Swedish shiba inu with a streak of fun-loving mischievousness. If your feed is in need of some inu inundation, follow @umigiva.

Last weekend, thousands of people like @_isalv gathered for the 13th Worldwide InstaMeet to celebrate Earth Day and explore nature while taking photos and videos together. Check out #LifeOnEarthWWIM13 and #WWIM13 to see how our amazing community celebrated in every corner of the world.

Photo by @_isalv

Last weekend, thousands of people like @elyasami gathered for the 13th Worldwide InstaMeet to celebrate Earth Day and explore nature while taking photos and videos together. Check out #LifeOnEarthWWIM13 and #WWIM13 to see how our amazing community celebrated in every corner of the world.

Photo by @elyasami

Last weekend, thousands of people like @aljvd gathered for the 13th Worldwide InstaMeet to celebrate Earth Day and explore nature while taking photos and videos together. Check out #LifeOnEarthWWIM13 and #WWIM13 to see how our amazing community celebrated in every corner of the world.

Photo by @aljvd

Claudia Burton Siller (@cburtonsiller) documents the small moments that warm our hearts and feel magical, like sun shining through a window. “As soon as my children wake up in the morning, I can see  early little light peeping behind the closed curtains,” Claudia, who lives with her family in Hermosillo, Mexico, says. “Every time I spot that light, I photograph everything: a cup of coffee, one of my kids or even myself.” She remembers to take photos so she won’t forget these times: “I don’t want to let go of the small details as they go away so suddenly. My pictures help me keep track of the everyday life of my family, the natural moments without a pose. They are like old photo albums.”
Photo by @cburtonsiller

One late night after dinner with friends, Lauren Purnell (@culinary_canvas) started playing with her leftover pasta: “I turned it into a tree ... and I just called it the spaghetree.” The 23-year-old Canadian-born, London-based brand strategist and part-time artist’s “tree” was a hit, and creating art out of food scraps became a new passion. Quickly, Lauren realized the best colors come from fresh food, so she started using what gets discarded in food prep — lots of skins, rinds, all the leftover bits. Her art is a means for repurposing these scraps before they’re tossed out. “I love the idea that my pieces could inspire people to stop wasting food,” Lauren says. She has labored over panda bears, florals and even scenes inspired by life in London, but her favorite pieces are the still the spontaneous ones.

Photo by @culinary_canvas

Not long ago, in the dry plains of La Mancha, there lived a gentleman of epic bravery and shiny armor. That man is former security guard José Ramón Gándara Alonso (@traslospasosdelquijote). Amazed by the heroism (and insanity) of Don Quixote, the title character of the novel by Miguel de #Cervantes, José Ramón quit his job to study photography and become the “21st Century Man of La Mancha.” Last summer, he built handmade armor out of upcycled goods — his shield was a former waiting tray and his helmet once served as a cooking bowl — before cycling under the blazing Spanish sun in search of adventure. “Some wizard changed my horse for a bizarre invention that had to be moved with pedals,” the knight from Castellón, Spain, says of his bicycle. He is ready to start the second leg of his journey as Don Quixote, marking the 400th anniversary of the passing of Miguel de Cervantes. 
For more stories from the Spanish-speaking community, follow @instagrames. 
Photo by @traslospasosdelquijote

Every week, we look back and highlight some of our favorite emerging voices across the globe, like this photo of Vienna in bloom captured by Alexandra Andreeva (@in_zhir), whose life as a medical student keeps her in the library. “The positive side of not having time to do anything but study is that it’s now much easier to notice this everyday beauty and be just like a tourist,” Alexandra says. 
For more of these photos, videos and news from around the community, visit blog.instagram.com.

Photo by @in_zhir

Every week, we look back and highlight some of our favorite emerging voices across the globe, like this photo by Silvia Miralles (@silvanamangana) of her friend Lulu (@laleleelulu). After buying a unicorn balloon, the pair took inspiration from an empty parking garage in Hamburg, Germany. “The light, the symmetry, the unicorn, Lulu ... everything fit together and turned into a magic picture,” says Silvia.

Photo by @silvanamangana

“#hellomynameis Brennen Taylor (@brennen), and I’m an actor from the San Fernando Valley in California. I try to entertain people through my videos, but social media changed my whole life, especially in the past year. I went from working in a mechanic shop, getting filthy in 100-degree [38 Celsius] valley heat, to supporting myself through my videos. 
I’ve met a ton of creators through social media who are so different from my high school friends — we all have the same passion to make people laugh; we all get each other. Because of the work I put into my videos, I get to travel; I get to go to events and hug the people who watch my content every week. That’s the best part about this whole thing. 
Obviously, I want the world to think I’m funny, but I’m always trying to promote positivity. I’ve realized that life is so short, and I want to tell my younger fans to be real, be you, have fun, and be happy. When I sit and think about how fast my own life has gone, I just want the people who watch my videos to remember to enjoy life, too.”
Follow @brennen as he meets fans, friends and fellow creators at #PlaylistLive this weekend. 
Video by @brennen

Leo Flores (@leofloresfotografia) is one of our featured voices from The Week on Instagram. He stumbled upon this group practicing capoeira on a beach in Brazil. “It was a beautiful day and I woke up early to photograph the sunrise,” he says. “Three guys did a synchronized jump to warm up and I decided to shoot. I like the feeling that they are flying.”
Photo by @leofloresfotografia

Simona Buratti (@simona_br_photography) is one of our featured voices from The Week on Instagram. Her photo of a lenticular cloud was taken near the Jökulsárlón glacier lagoon in Iceland. “I’ve always liked to play with the human element in big landscapes,” says Simona, who was on the road with her partner Arnar Kristjansson (@arnarkristjans_photography). “Standing in front of that cloud was a great moment. I still feel the goosebumps.”
Photo by @simona_br_photography

Growing up, @ursulaholliday listened to punk music. “Everyone just thought I was weird,” the 18-year-old drummer tells Instagram @music. Luckily, she had kindred spirits in sister @delilahholliday, 19, and cousin @ameliasayaka, 20. So they started playing songs together, channeling their feminist-first, working-class message into @skinnygirldietband, an energetic, balls-to-the-wall punk group that counts the Powerpuff Girls as role models. “I used to love Bubbles so much, I was like, I have got to play drums,” says Ursula. “Blossom played guitar,” adds Delilah. “And then Buttercup over here,” replies Ursula, while pointing to Amelia, “played bass.”
Photo by @skinnygirldietband. Words by @music

British artist Jason Decaires Taylor’s (@jason_decaires_taylor) sculptures live under the sea. His newest aquatic installation is on display at the Atlantic Museum, an underwater museum off the coast of Lanzarote, one of the Canary Islands. “A lot of the narrative of the sculptures is about global warming, about a denial of what’s happening to our resources,” he says of his sculptures. “On a practical level, they are designed to encourage people to go into the ocean, to get to know more about the environment.” Made from a special type of marine cement, the life-size pieces host different species of sponge, coral and fish. “I am hoping that in the future they will be completely inundated with life and transformed,” he says. #EarthDay

Photo by @jason_decaires_taylor

The 13th Worldwide InstaMeet is finally here! Thousands of people will spend Earth Day weekend (April 22-24) celebrating the wonder and beauty of the planet while exploring nature and taking photos and videos together.
